definitions.definition: (in the UK) a man of high rank in the nobility (= people of high social class), or somebody who has been given the title ‘lord’ as an honour

examples.text: The head of the successful construction group became a lord in 1984.
They entered a huge hall filled with lords and ladies.

definitions.definition: (in the UK) the title used by a lord

examples.text: He was made a peer and took the title Lord Northcliffe.

definitions.definition: a title used for some high official positions in the UK
(in the UK) a title of respect used when speaking to a judge, bishop or some male members of the nobility (= people of high social class)
a powerful man in medieval Europe, who owned a lot of land and property
a title used to refer to God or Christ

examples.text: Love the Lord with all your heart.

definitions.definition: a title used to refer to Christ
(in the UK) the part of Parliament whose members are not elected by the people of the country

examples.text: The Lords has/have not yet reached a decision.

definitions.definition: the building where members of the House of Lords meet
used to show that you are surprised, annoyed or worried about something

examples.text: Good Lord, what have you done to your hair!

definitions.definition: used to emphasize what you are saying

examples.text: Lord knows, I tried to teach her.

definitions.definition: used to say that you do not know the answer to something
any particular year after the birth of Christ

wordOrigin: Old English hlāford, from hlāfweard ‘bread-keeper’, from a Germanic base (see loaf (noun), ward). Compare with lady.
